THE SECRETARY OF STATE FOR HOME AFFAIRS informed theWar Cabinet that a member of the staff of the Portuguese embassy had "been found to "be carrying out espionage; for the enemy.The Embassy had waived any claim to diplomatic privilege andhad dismissed the man, whereupon he had been arrested and triedunder the Treachery Act and condemned to death, the trialbeing held in camera.The Portuguese Government had asked that the death penalty should not be carried out, and had indicated that theywere ready to do what they could to clear up the Germanespionage ring in Lisbon. He had discussed the matter withthe Foreign Secretary, and after full consideration had reachedthe conclusion that it would be in the public interest tocommute the death sentence, seeing that we should thereby *obtain the good will of the Portuguese Government in rootingout German espionage from their country.It was the usual practice, in cases where the death'sentence had been imposed after a trial in camera, to make some public statement giving the result of the trial andsuch of the facts of the case as could safely be disclosed;and in this particular case the Judge, before agreeing to hear the case in camera, had asked, for and had received anaistaurance that such a public statement woixld be made. as things had turned out, however, it would be difficult to makeany public announcement at this juncture since a convincing-explanation of the commutation of sentence could not be given without revealing matters which it was in the public interestshould be kept secret. On the whole, notwithstanding the obvious objections to not publishing the results of trialsheld in secret, he was against making any public statement.This view met with the general approval of the WarCabinet. It was pointed out that the objections to withholdingany public statement regarding the results of such trialsapplied with far less force where the death sentence had beencommuted. As the prisoner had been reprieved., it would bepossible to make some nublic announcement at a later date, when-She facts could be made known without detriment to the publicinterest.Offices of. the War Cabinet,S.W. 1. ,27th May, 1943.
